> Will it be possible to validate the new structure at all?
>
The org.archive.settings.file.Validator class is a command-line tool  
for validating a configuration. Give it a try and let us know what  
you think.

> I think the sense of structure is a fairly important baby to be  
> throwing
> out with the bathwater.
>
Usually overrides aren't structured at all.

> We're actually in NetarchiveSuite moving
> towards something that's uses the XML structure more rather than  
> seeing
> it as key-value pairs.
>
Can you divulge any more details about that? I'm particularly  
interested in how XML-vs-non-XML sheets would affect your integration  
with us.

> It's obviously bad to have a different format for modifying sheets,  
> but
> couldn't the JMX API use XML instead, passing arbitrary parts of a  
> sheet
> XML?
>
Well, then we'd be using two APIs for configuration management.

> I get nervous twitches every time I see something evolve from fairly
> simple to having its own type system (having done that too many times
> myself:). It's a sign that it's getting too complex.
>
The 2.0 settings system uses the same types as the the 1.x settings  
system. There are simple and complex types; complex types can be  
modules, maps or lists. 2.0 adds some new simple types (Java  
enumerations, and java.util.regex.Pattern), and uses Java generics  
where possible. Also in 1.x, module types had to extend from a base  
class; in 2.x this is not strictly required, though we do encourage  
module writers to implement a Module tagging interface.

> We've talked occasionally about using Spring for settings. I don't  
> know
> yet if Spring is the best, but wouldn't it be more reasonable to  
> follow
> some kind of standard for settings files rather than re-inventing the
> wheel (much as that is a favorite passtime of programmers:)?
>
I'm actually a fan of Spring, but it turned out not to be a good  
match for Heritrix's needs.

Spring configuration files would be great for establishing the global  
configuration, but the value of a module's setting depends on the URI  
currently being processed. Eg, you might want to set the Frontier to  
allow some domains to be crawled faster than others, or you might not  
want to crawl certain paths on one server but still crawl other paths  
on that same server.  There's no direct way to express those sorts of  
overrides using Spring (let alone our somewhat strange way of adding  
override elements to lists and maps).

Indirectly, we could have one standard Spring config for the global  
configuration, and use some custom format for describing the  
overrides. But then we'd need to write custom code for injecting the  
overrides into the main Spring config, then using Spring to  
regenerate the override configuration for the URI. That seemed overly  
burdensome to have to do for every URI.

-Paul
